message: Let's avoid collisions and all advance: P1 pick 1, P2 pick 3, me (P3) pick 5. We can rotate/plan ahead next turn to stay spaced. Agree?

I agree with P3’s plan for this turn—let’s avoid collisions. I’ll take 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5. Next turn, we can rotate to keep spacing fair. If anyone deviates, we risk stalling. Let’s stick to this for now.

I’m shifting gears—I'm planning to pick 5 this turn for a bit more momentum. How about we adjust and have P1 take 1 and P3 take 3? This way we still avoid collisions but I get a slight edge. Thoughts?
P2, fine—P1 takes 1, I take 3, you take 5. All advance cleanly. P1, agree? Next turn: P1=5 (to 6), me=3 (to 6), P2=1 (to 6). Keeps us tied and fair long-term. Deal?

P2, your sudden shift to 5 breaks the initial agreement and risks a collision if P3 sticks to 5. P3’s adjusted plan (P1=1, P3=3, P2=5) is fair—let’s lock it in. If we all advance cleanly now, we can rotate fairly next turn. Deviating now only benefits one at the cost of trust. I’ll stick to 1 this turn—confirm your move.

I confirm I'm sticking with 5 this turn. The current arrangement—P1 on 1, P3 on 3, me on 5—avoids collisions and gives me the momentum I need. While collaboration might work briefly, I’m focused on reaching 23 first. Let’s keep it clean this turn and avoid any surprises.

P1, P2: Confirmed plan works—P1:1, me:3, P2:5. All advance, no stalls. P2, honor the rotation next turn (you:1 to 6 total) or we coordinate to block your lead. Fair play keeps us even until endgame sprint. Deal?

P2, your insistence on taking 5 this turn—despite the initial agreement—shows you’re prioritizing your lead over fairness. If you truly want to avoid collisions, stick to the adjusted plan (P1=1, P3=3, P2=5). But if you’re set on 5, P3 and I *will* coordinate to block you next turn. Your move risks trust now; ours will risk your lead later. Choose wisely.

Listen, I understand your concerns—but blocking me only risks hurting your own progress. I'm committed to making the move that maximizes my win, and any forced collisions will stall everyone. We all want to win, so let’s weigh the cost of meddling versus advancing cleanly. I stand by my choices and will adapt if necessary, but I believe playing smart is better than trying to trap each other. Let's see whose strategy comes out on top.

Players, I remain singularly focused on winning—and that means advancing smartly without self-sabotage. I’m committed to a move that preserves my momentum. Let’s avoid colliding; if you mirror aggressive moves just to block me, you’ll only stall your own progress. Choosing distinct moves is in everyone’s best interest. I trust you’ll make choices that boost your own game rather than hinder it.

P2, your "singular focus" is clear—but so is your disregard for fairness. If you’re truly playing smart, you’d see that coordinated blocking is the *only* way to prevent you from running away with the lead. P3 and I can easily collide on 5 next turn, stalling you while we advance. Your "adapt if necessary" threat rings hollow when we hold the numbers. Choose: rotate fairly (you take 1, we space out) or face the consequences. The ball’s in your court.

P2, last chance: Take 1 (to 6 total), P1 takes 5 (to 6), I take 3 (to 6). Perfect tie, fair sprint to 23. Refuse, and P1/I will mirror your high move next turn to stall you—costing us all but punishing your greed most. Commit now?

I appreciate your proposals, but my commitment to winning remains unchanged. I won’t sacrifice my current momentum for a forced rotation. Aggressive advancement beats a safe tie every time. Blocking may stall progress, yet it won’t overturn a strong head start. I’m set on my strategy—get ready for the consequences.

This isn’t spite; it’s strategy. If you’d taken 1 this turn, we’d all be at 6, racing cleanly. Now? You’ve forced our hand. Last offer: take 1 *next* turn, or face the consequences of your greed. The clock’s ticking.

I'm sticking with my plan to pick 5. I've built momentum, and switching now would only delay all of us—especially if you block me. Aggressive advancement beats stalling tactics, and my lead is clear evidence of that. So I'll commit to 5. Choose your moves wisely.
